PageElement.TextBox:
On the following pages you will be asked %System_NumberOfQuestions% questions about the Introduction to Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines.

You may be asked 3 different types of questions: multiple choice, true/false or yes/no. Answer each question by clicking the button to the left of the most appropriate response.

After you answer the last question, you will be given the chance to review and then submit your answers.

Please note that if you Exit the quiz before clicking the Submit Answers button then your answers will not be saved.

To move between questions, use the ◄and ► navigation buttons on the bottom right of the page.

PageElement.Question:
Who must comply with the CPGs?


All Commonwealth government bodies.
Only agencies governed by the Financial Management and Accountability Act (FMA Act Agencies) because the CPGs are a policy issued under the Financial Management and Accountability Regulations.
FMA Act Agencies, and CAC Act bodies which have been directed to comply by the Finance Minister.
All organisations (including private sector organisations) that are procuring goods or services that will be paid for by taxpayers .
All Commonwealth budget funded organisations that have been directed to comply by the Finance Minister.

If a FMA Act agency issues a tender for a two year contract (estimated value of $70,000) with an option for the Agency to extend the Contract for a further year (estimated value $35,000) is it a covered procurement under the CPGs?


Yes.  The procurement as a whole will be a covered procurement under the CPGs because a second procurement process is not required to exercise the option.
No, because the procurement is below the threshold.
No, but the Agency is required to decide when it exercises the option whether or not the additional procurement it is value for money.
Only when the Agency decides to exercise the option.

What should you take into account in value for money assessments?  


Cost.
Cost and risk.
Cost and flexibility to adapt to changes over the life of the procurement.
Costs as well as any non financial benefits.
All of the above.

Why is it important to facilitate SME participation in Australian government procurement as part of determining value for money?


To support Australian businesses.
To encourage competition.
To ensure ethical use of resources.

If an Agency conducts a two stage covered procurement process – a request for expressions of interest followed by a select request for tender - how long do the CPGs require that the select request for tender process be open to responses for?


At least 10 calendar days
Any length of time (but at least as long as reasonably necessary to respond)
At least 25 calendar days
At least 30 calendar days

If the Australian Defence Force requires boots for ADF personnel being deployed, what is the minimum time limit that can be set for responding to a request for tender on AusTender?


Any length of time.
At least 10 calendar days.
At least 25 business days.
At least 25 calendar days.

Should agencies keep all information about contracts and suppliers confidential?


Yes always, unless written consent is obtained from the supplier.
Only where the information is actually confidential.  All confidential information should be kept confidential subject to complying with government reporting requirements under the principle of accountability and transparency.
Yes always, except where there is an exception set out in the relevant contract.
Yes always, but only until the request for tender process is finalised.  After the request for tender process the government is required to make information available to the public.
Yes, but only until the request for tender process is finalised.  Once the tender process is finalised, only information specified in a contract is protected as confidential.

In addition to any requirements for covered procurements, the efficient, effective and ethical use of resources requires agencies to:


A) Establish protocols for dealing with current suppliers to ensure that all organisations invited to tender have received the same information in relation to a procurement.
B) Offer industry briefings and information sessions to potential providers where necessary to ensure an adequate understanding of the procurement process and the Agency's requirements.
C) Invite as many potential suppliers to tender as possible in order to maximise competition.
D) All of the above
E) A) and B)

What information are agencies usually required to publish about their contracts?


Agencies must publish the details on AusTender within six weeks of contract signature.  This includes the name of the contracting parties, the nature of the contract, and the total value of the contract.
Unless the contract delegate approves a media statement, both the agency and the supplier should keep the details of the contract confidential.
Agencies must publish the details in the Commonwealth Government gazette within six after weeks of contract signature.  This includes the name of the contracting parties, the nature of the contract, and the total value of the contract.
Agencies must place a copy of the contract on their website within six weeks after contract signature.

An agency wants to make the tender submission deadline 10 days after the tender release.  In which of the following circumstances is that permissible?


The agency has done extensive research which demonstrates that the only companies that will be interested are those that are already very familiar with the agency's requirements and so will not need 25 days to write a response.
The agency's current contract for the services will expire next month and the agency has no further options to extend.  Unless a new contract is entered into, the agency's operations will be disrupted.
The agency has already undertaken an expression of interest process for the procurement to limit the number of potential suppliers.
The agency has published all the details of the tender in their Annual Procurement Plan released at least two months ago.

What is a select tender?


A select tender is a tender process which involves publishing of a tender inviting responses from any organisation.
A select tender is any tender that is undertaken in a genuine state of urgency.
A select tender is a tender process which involves the issue of request documentation to only one or a limited number of potential suppliers selected by the Agency.
A select tender is a tender process where an Agency is permitted to select the successful tenderer on the basis that they have previously provided services to the Australian Government.

What is the monetary threshold over which all Commonwealth contracts and amendments to these arrangements, must be published on the AusTender website?


Details of all contracts and any amendments must be published.
Details of all contracts over $100,000 (and any amendments that bring the total contract price to over $100,000) must be published.
For FMA agencies the reporting requirements apply to all contracts over $10,000. CAC Act bodies are not required to report their contracts on AusTender.
For FMA agencies the reporting requirements apply to all contracts over $10,000. For CAC Act bodies the threshold is $9 million for procurement of construction services and $400,000 for other procurements.

For covered procurements, what is the threshold for all construction services?


$80,000.00
$400,000.00
$11 million
$9 million

An agency wants to avoid the covered procurement threshold in the CPGs by separating a procurement into parts; in what circumstance is this allowed?


By having separate contracts for different aspects of the goods and services that are being procured, so that no single contract is over the threshold.
Where the agency is procuring different components from separate suppliers, and the total being procured from any one supplier will not exceed the covered procurement threshold.
By entering into a deed arrangement where individual work orders are issued, and each of the work orders are for less than the covered procurement threshold.
When the total contract value may be over the threshold, but can not be accurately calculated at the time that the contract is entered into.

Which of the following tender requirements would be inconsistent with the CPGs


That no agency data be permitted to be taken outside of Australia
That the tenderer comply with all applicable laws and Australian government policies in performing the contract
That the tenderer demonstrate it has previously undertaken similar work for the public sector
That the tenderer provide the services from a specific location in Sydney.
That the tenderer be incorporated in Australia, or an Australian resident for taxation purposes.

Which legislation is most relevant to financial management of Commonwealth agencies?


Fiscal Maintenance and Accountability Act and the Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Act
Financial Management and Accountability Act.
Financial Maintenance and Accountability Act and the Constitution
None, financial management requirements are all set out in the CPGs.
Financial Management and Accountability Act and the Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Act.

PageElement.TextBox:
You have reached the end of the quiz.

You can now review or change your answers. Use the navigation buttons to move between questions.

When you are happy with your answers, click the Submit Answers button below. You will then see whether you passed the quiz.
